This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. Emergency response drills are conducted on a regular basis. These drills create and sustain a high degree of accident response awareness by creating what if situations that stimulate thinking and improve readiness of personnel to cope with a variety of emergency situations. These drills can include outside agencies (e.g. LEPC, Honolulu Fire Department), and participants treat the hypothetical drill situations and respond accordingly. In addition, the refinery is a participating member of the Campbell Local Emergency Action Network (C.L.E.A.N.). This network's purpose is to promote emergency preparedness issues, including public safety and health in the Campbell Industrial Park (CIP) where the refinery is located. The CIP Emergency Resources Guide is a vital resource produced by CLEAN. The resources guide is used in conjunction with the refinery emergency plan in the event that notifications to neighboring businesses are necessary during a refinery incident.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

o	The refinery routinely makes changes to procedures, equipment, training programs and materials in order to improve safety and reduce environmental impacts.  These changes are made as a result of HAZOP studies, accident and near-miss investigations, safety inspections, pre-startup reviews and audits.

Par Hawaii Refining - Par West Refinery 
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
 June 2019

The Risk Management Plan (RMP) was developed in accord with EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Regulations coded in 40 CFR 68. It is intended to prevent and limit the impact of potentially toxic and flammable substances from being accidentally released by the refinery. The RMP includes a facility-wide review of potential hazards, a worst-case, alternative case and off-site consequences analysis, and implements a formal management system for managing and minimizes those risks.   The RMP is just one element of Par's commitment to safety and protection of employees, the surrounding community and environment. 

SAFETY COMMITMENT

The following corporate policy statement expresses Par's overall commitment to safety and the prevention of accidental releases which could impact the community.  

Par considers safety an integral part of its performance.  At Par we believe:
¿	All accidents can be prevented.
¿	Safety is not to be compromised for any reason.
¿	Each employee is responsible for their own safety and working safely is a condition of employment.
¿	Management is accountable for accident prevention
¿	Trained employees are an essential element for safe workplaces.
¿	All operating exposures can be safeguarded.
¿	Immediate corrective action shall be taken on all unsafe practices and incidents with injury or damage potential. 

Complying with the requirements of OSHA's Process Management System (PSM) and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) will help protect employees as well as the surrounding communities and environment. 

DESCRIPTION OF SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Par West Refinery is located on the island of Oahu, Hawaii. The Refinery operates several processing units to produce petroleum products (e.g. jet, naphtha diesel, fuel oil, propane) from crude oil. 

Portions of the refinery are subject to regulation under EPA's Risk Management P

rogram specified by 40 CFR 68 because more than 10,000 lbs of flammable mixtures are stored or processed on-site. Flammable mixtures include methane, ethane, ethylene, propane, butane, and pentane and light and whole straight run naphtha and are generally produced as a consequence of refining crude oil.  There are no toxic substances stored on-site in excess of the threshold quantities, specified by 40 CFR 68. 
 
In December of 2018 the refinery was subdivided into a bulk terminal facility and refinery process units. Par Hawaii Refining acquired the crude and vacuum units and utility systems required to sustain their operations.  The supporting utility system include a flare/relief system, 2 boilers and 4 cogeneration units and the Effluent Treatment Plant (ETP) which is used to treat waste water before it is discharged through NPDES permitted outfall to the Pacific Ocean.   Par Hawaii Refining purchased some additional process units including the acid plant, hydrogen manufacturing unit, hydrogenation and isomerization unit and several columns in the FCC and alkylation plants, but these units are not being operated. Because there are no plans to operate them at this time, the idled equipment has been isolated and purged with nitrogen.  Although refinery fuel gas and light naphtha are present and used as fuels to fire the boilers and  cogeneration units, the amount flammable substances (fuel)  in the supply lines is well below the 10,000 lb applicability threshold criteria established under 40 CFR 68.  Because much of the refinery has been idled and purged, most of the flammable mixtures are generated and held within the crude unit (which includes the vacuum unit and vapor recovery system).
 
In addition to the crude unit, the refinery has two flares, which are or can be inter-connected. When the flammable mixtures associated with both flares is aggregated as a singular system, the flares are also considered a covered process under RMP. 


GENERAL ACCIDENTAL R

ELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention programs in place at the Par West Refinery. Processes at the refinery that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. This summary describes each RMP Program 3 Prevention Program in place at the refinery, which are aligned with the OSHA PSM elements. The objective of the RMP prevention programs and the PSM system is to reduce the consequences and/or likelihood of potential accidents at the refinery.

¿	Employee Participation
o	Employees are actively involved in each element of the RMP prevention program at the refinery. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents, operating & maintenance procedures, and chemical information, to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information generated from the refinery accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees are involved in the accident prevention programs are documented in an employee participation policy that is maintained at the refinery. In addition, the refinery has a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues. These initiatives often include forming committees to address process and personal safety. The committees typically have members from various workgroups, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and plant management. Regularly scheduled meetings are held with various employee groups to address a variety of process and personal safety topics.

¿	Incident Investigation
o	The refinery promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire or explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental release, or personal injury. The goal of each in

vestigation is to determine the cause(s) and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to Refinery management for review and approval. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with employees and contractors who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHA studies. Management reviews are regularly performed to ensure the quality of investigation program.

¿	Process Safety Information
o	The refinery maintains a variety of procedures, drawings and technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents contain safety related information on topics such as process operation, process equipment, chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters, and equipment design basis. The documents which are categorized as process safety information are defined in a policy maintained at the refinery. Specific departments within the refinery are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. All process safety information is available to all employees.

¿	Process Hazard Analysis
o	The refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with each process are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The primary technique used to perform process hazard evaluations (PHA) is known as the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis. HAZOP analysis is

recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analysis is conducted by a team of people with expertise in process operations, engineering, reliability and maintenance. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures based on risk criteria. The team's recommendations are reviewed with the appropriate management representatives and after concurrence, the recommendation list is distributed for follow-up and communicated to all affected employees. A copy of the final report is maintained in the refinery main library and is available to all employees. The PHA team's recommendations are assigned to individuals to develop action plans for resolution. The action plans are tracked to ensure that all items are completed in a timely manner. Actions taken to resolve recommendations are reviewed and approved by management and documented in a system maintained at the refinery. PHA's are revalidated at least every five years. The revalidation includes a review of the changes (design, regulatory, etc.) that have taken place in the process since the last HAZOP analysis, as well as incidents in the process unit and in other similar units in the refining industry. The revalidation includes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation recommendations as done during the initial HAZOP analysis.

¿	Operating Procedures
o	The Refinery maintains written operating procedures addressing each Plant's operational processes including start-up, normal operations, emergency shutdown, planned shutdown, and the initial start-up of a new plant or after a planned maintenance shutdown. These procedures are used by operations personnel and provide a basis for consistent training new operations personnel. These procedures are reviewed and certified annually as current and accurate. The procedures are maintaine

d current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change (MOC) process. 

¿	Training
o	To complement the written procedures for process operations, the refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New operators must first successfully complete a comprehensive series of classroom training sessions on refinery operations. The new operators are then paired up with more experienced operator to learn process specific procedures, duties and tasks. After the new operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) they have an adequate knowledge to perform the plant operating duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. The operator is then fully qualified upon completion of the Formal Operating Training Program requirements. In addition, operations personnel receive refresher training on operating procedures at least every 3 years to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained. All training is documented and kept on record in the Refinery's Training and Development Department.

¿	Contractors
o	The Par West Refinery uses contract personnel to supplement our workforce, primarily to perform maintenance work, including during shutdowns and construction projects. Contracting companies are selected based on their work performance and their safety systems, including their safety incident rates, the quality of their safety programs, policies, and processes, and their training programs. The contracting companies which perform work on process equipment must also subscribe to a third-party review and must achieve an acceptable rating in order to continue working in the refinery. Prior to working in the refinery, all contractors must attend a refinery orientation. Contractors working in office buildings view a short video covering key safety, environmental, emergency, and security procedures and policies. Con

tractors working in the refinery operating areas must attend a lengthier classroom training session that covers the same categories of topics but is geared towards hazards associated with work on or around the process equipment. In addition, the classroom training covers specific refinery safe work practices (e.g. permit to work, hot work, equipment isolation) and other related process hazards. The refinery also requires contractors to participate in key activates, such as tailgate meetings, safety and environmental audits, and work audits. Requirements for each contractor are monitored by refinery personnel who oversee each contracting company. The refinery has established a Contractor Safety Council to help review and improve the safety performance of contractors and refinery work processes. Representatives from all contract companies are encouraged to participate.

¿	Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
o	The refinery conducts a PSSR on new facilities and facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, such as, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

¿	Mechanical Integrity
o	Mechanical Integrity includes all activities required to ensure proper design, construction, and ongoing integrity and reliability of equipment in order to prevent or minimize incidents for the life of the equipment. The Refinery has several written programs in place that detail well-

established practices and procedures for the inspection, testing, monitoring, and maintenance of process equipment, tankage and utilities, and instrumentation and safety systems. These practices and procedures are periodically reviewed and updated, and training is provided to impacted employees. The Refinery has specific support groups that specialize in the reliability of fixed equipment (e.g. piping, vessels) and rotating machinery (e.g. pumps, compressors). These trained support personnel are responsible for performing inspections and tests to ensure safe equipment operations. If safety or operational issues with equipment are identified, plans are developed to correct the deficiency. Members of these groups are also consulted when buying new equipment or machinery or when a design changes are being considered. 

o	Safe Work Practices 
o	The Par West Refinery has safe work practices in place that help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include but are not limited to: 
	1) the control of the entry, presence, and exit of personnel into confined spaces or other hazardous work areas, 
	2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, 
	3) procedures for the safe removal of substances that may be hazardous before equipment is opened for inspection and/or maintenance, 
	4) a permit procedure to control activities that maybe a source of ignition (i.e., hot work), and 
	5) the controlled entry of personnel into plant areas. 
These and other procedures, along with training of personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

o	Management of Change
o	The refinery has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be

properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to
	(1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and
	(2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. 
The change passes through several phases of review with an emphasis placed on the type of change and the impact of that change. The MOC requests are tracked, and once all the required reviews are completed the MOC is given an authorization to implement and start up the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. Training about the change is provided to affected personnel.

o	Compliance Audits
o	Periodic compliance audits are conducted at the refinery to help ensure procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are effectively implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years with an audit team composed of various subject matter experts from within the company who are not employed by the refinery. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are maintained at the refinery.

Although the Crude Unit is the only process covered by RMP, the rest of the Par West refinery is subject to and operates in accord with PSM requirements.  

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Based on equations from 40 CFR part 68 as prescribed by the EPA, the release and ignition of light hydrocarbons from the atmospheric distillation tower (V-5100), the largest single vessel in the crude unit (and assuming that its entire flammable mixture was butane) would lead to a Worst-Case vapor cloud explosion (VCE) creating a 1 psi over-pressurization that wo

uld extend  1,728 feet. Because the refinery is located along the Pacific Ocean in an industrial area, residential communities would not be impacted by the VCE.   .   Similarly based on equations from 40 CFR part 68, the release and ignition of light hydrocarbons from the atmospheric overhead accumulator vessel (V-5101) in the crude unit (also assuming that its entire flammable mixture was butane) would lead to a the alternative scenario VCE creating a 1 psi over-pressurization that would extend  761 feet. For this smaller scenario, there are no offsite consequences, aside from the adjacent IES Downstream LLC terminal.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Refinery processes have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention programs summarized in the previous section applies to all Program 3 RMP covered processes and all PSM regulated processes at the Refinery. Collectively these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and/or human error. The Refinery also has safety features designed into process units to quickly detect, contain and control, and reduce/mitigate the consequences of the release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:
o	Release Detection:
o	Low/High pressure alarms.
o	Low/High level alarms.
o	Hydrocarbon detection alarms.
o	Hydrogen sulfide detection alarms.

o	Release Containment/Control:
o	Process relief valves that relieve to the flare system for incineration.
o	Emergency block valves to enable quick manual or automated isolation of the processes.
o	Automatic shutdown systems which activate on specific process parameters (e.g. high level, high temperature, no flow)
o	Areas surrounded by berms to contain liquid releases
o	Spill containment equipment - absorbent pads and boom
o	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (continuous power supply for control systems, backup pumps) 
o	Atmosphe

ric relief devices

o	Release Mitigation:
o	Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
o	Deluge systems on specific equipment
o	Trained emergency response team
o	Personal protective equipment
o	Blast-proof control buildings (personnel & control system protection).

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

A review of incident reports covering the past five years (including while the facility was owned by Chevron and IES Downstream) was conducted to determine whether any incidents met the RMP Five Year Accident History incident reporting criteria. No accidents were identified that met these criteria.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Refinery maintains a written emergency response plan which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is released accidentally. The plan includes:
o	Procedures and information on all aspects of emergency response 
o	Organizational structures and roles of personnel during emergency response
o	Firefighting equipment and procedures
o	Internal and external assistance (manpower & equipment resources)
o	First aid and medical attention procedures
o	Evacuation Plans
o	Fire Response Plans
o	Spill and Release Plans
o	Notification procedures for government agencies in the event of an offsite or reportable release.
o	Testing and maintenance procedures of emergency response equipment

The overall emergency response program for the Par West Refinery is coordinated with the Honolulu Department of Emergency Management (DEM) which serves as the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) for the city and county of Honolulu. This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which has members from the local emergency response community, local government officials, and industry representatives.
